entry.title: bug #91 (submitted): Incoherence between bnf rules and example in the HTTP rendering
entry.content:
A lot of examples in the "RESTful HTTP Rendering" document are ending with a trailing ";". In particular, the example about Category or Link.
But when you look at the bnf definition in page 19 and 20, a ";" can only appears between 2 actual category-value or link-value.
Then, inside the http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2616.txt, section 4.2, there is nothing that introduce an extra ";" and the end of message header.

Can you tell me if i missed something in the document ?.

draft #69 (submitted): Link / noReturnTraffic
entry.content:
The current description of the noReturnTraffic parameter of a Link is somewhat cryptic:

noReturnTraffic. A value of true changes the definition of Link to: data transport from each sources to all sinks, except that there is no data transport from a source to a sink if the source and sink are grouped together in a BidirectionalPort group. The default value of noReturnTraffic is false.

This should be updated to explain better what it means.

entry.title: draft #55 (submitted): Equate adaptation stacks
entry.content:
Taken from: https://forge.ogf.org/sf/go/artf6587?nav=1

It is yet unclear how to deal with changes in technology descriptions over time. New technologies are easy: just add a
new encoding or schema. For existing adaptation stacks this is harder.

Imagine that IP over Ethernet is defined as an adaptation that ignores the EtherType or the QoS bits in the VLAN header,
but due to some changes in Ethernet or IP it is deemed necessary to describe it at a stack of two adaptations:
EtherType over VLAN and IP over EtherType. It is likely that during such transition two schemas will be used at the same
time. This makes it necessary to be able to say that one adaptation stack is really the same as another adaptation
stack.

We need a proposal to define how this is done.

entry.title: draft #54 (submitted): [Tech] Ethernet technology proposal
entry.content:
Taken from: https://forge.ogf.org/sf/go/artf6588?nav=1

We need a Ethernet technology description (with VLANs, Q-in-Q, perhaps a distinction between C- and S-VLANs, etc.) so
that early adopters of NML can describe Ethernet in a standard way.

entry.title: draft #52 (submitted): Define derived relations
entry.content:
Taken from: https://forge.ogf.org/sf/go/artf6564?nav=1

NML is flexible, but that comes at the price that it is often possible to describe a network in different ways, often in
more or less detail.

The shorter description can often be expanded to a longer description by using some logic.

Example 1:
<Topology X> locatedAt <Location L>,
<Topology X> hasTopology <Topology Y>
implies:
<Topology Y> locatedAt <Location L>,

Example 2:
<PortGroup PG> hasPort <Port P>
<Port P> hasLabel <Label v>
<PortGroup G> isSource <LinkGroup LG>
<LinkGroup PG> hasLink <Link L>
<Link L> hasLabel <Label v>
implies:
<Port P> isSource <Link L>

We need to define this logic in our document.
